questions.question_title: What are the insured requirements for ‘Overseas StudyCare Insurance’?
questions.question_answer: The insured must be between the ages of 12 to 65 with a valid HKID and holds an overseas full time student visa, and an acceptance letter from the educational institution. If the insured aged 12-17, the application should be made by his/her parent.

questions.question_title: If I need to stay in another country for exchange or leisure purposes while studying overseas, am I covered?
questions.question_answer:
The policy provides Worldwide cover. If you are travelling for leisure during your study trip, the plan will only cover the following areas:
  1. Medical Expenses
  2. Top up In-Patient Medical Expenses
  3. Worldwide Emergency Assistance Services
  4. Personal Accident
  5. Travel Delay
  6. Baggage
  7. Personal Liability

questions.question_title: Which countries are included as Asian Countries?
Under what circumstances is the beneficiary able to receive Double Indemnity?
questions.question_answer:
If any of the scenarios below occur, the beneficiary will receive Double Indemnity:
  1. The Insured Student was travelling as a fare paying passenger on a public conveyance which was involved in an accident and died
  2. The Insured Student died if he/she was an innocent bystander in a gun battle between the police and another person or person; or
  3. The Insured Student was unable to escape a fire within any residential building and died

questions.question_title: When would I receive benefits for a burn injury?
questions.question_answer: We will award benefits if the Insured Student suffers third degree burns from an accident while on a journey, however, this benefit may only be claimed once for each accident during the journey.

questions.question_title: If the Insured Student is kidnapped overseas during their period of study, what benefits will be awarded?
questions.question_answer:
In this tragic event of kidnapping, we will offer the following benefits (only applicable to Worldwide or Asia only Plan A):
  1. Compassionate Visit and Hotel Accommodation – Provided to up to 2 immediate family members, including travelling costs to the location of the educational institution where the Insured Student was kidnapped. (Accommodations up to HK$1,200 per person per night for 5 consecutive days)
  2. Compassionate Death Benefit – compensation for the Accidental Death of Insured Student from injury inflicted during the kidnapping incident up to HK$250,000.

questions.question_title: If in the event that the Insured Student was kidnapped, and was killed during a gun battle between the kidnappers and the police, what benefits will be awarded?
questions.question_answer: If the Insured Student was kidnapped and then killed in the following gun battle, the claim will also fall under section 4 b – Personal Accident awarded Double Indemnity at the maximum limit to HK$1,000,000. (Please note that Section 7b – Kidnapping Compassionate death benefit will not be applicable)

questions.question_title: If the Insured Student was kidnapped but I failed to report it to the relevant authorities within 24 hours, will he/she still be awarded benefits?
questions.question_answer: If it has been discovered that the Insured Student has been kidnapped, notification must be made to the relevant authorities within 24 hours of that time.

questions.question_title: If the Insured Student is kidnapped when he/she is travel out of the country of the Overseas Educational institution attended during the school holiday, will benefits be awarded?
questions.question_answer: If the Insured Student is on a trip away from his/her country of the educational institution no benefits will be awarded.

questions.question_title: If the Insured Student lives in on-campus accommodation, will this be covered within the Education Fund?
questions.question_answer: The Education Fund only covers unpaid tuition fees (excluding overdue fees). Any accommodation fees, off campus study tours, amusement courses or consumables are excluded from this benefit.
